## Objectives of the study {.smaller}

::: {.center-y40}

Identify and propose local priority areas to be preserved for the protection of wading birds, as the Eurasian curlew as flagship species.

Understand how the Eurasian curlew uses space in a functional site comprising the Marennes basin and the Brouage marshes, in a context maritimization and strong anthropogenic pressures (hunting, shellfish gathering, oyster farming). 

:::

## Space use analyses - Methods {.smaller}

Main used area estimated with Utilization Distribution (UD) function and the kernel method.

<div style="font-size:60%; color:gray;">
The bandwidth parameter *h* has been fixed for each analyses as the half the estimated Silverman rules values (depending on the variance in latitude and longitude locations) for a fine-grained scale details (functions <span style="font-family:'Courier New', Courier, monospace;">kernelUD</span> and <span style="font-family:'Courier New', Courier, monospace;">getverticeshr</span> from the R package "adehabitatHR", Calenge 2006, and see Worton, 1995)
</div>

Random sampling of 1000 GPS points per individual per categories.

## To sum up {.smaller} 

- Roosting and foraging areas highly variables among individuals
  - **Restricted** population **surfaces** during the **hunting** season

- Individual distance between roosting and foraging seems to vary according to 
  - *age : sex* = **juvenile males** seems to **go further away** to roost vs feed
  - *sex : spring vs neap tide* = **male** stay **closer** when spring tide
  - *hunting schedule* = birds **avoid hunting cabin** when hunters are allowed to shoot (at night)
  
## Some limits and drawbacks {.smaller} 

- We (always) need more individuals, years and points 

- It would have been very useful to have 
  - detailed data about hunting pressures
  - data about fishing and fishing pressures
  
- Studying individual 3D movements to have access to detailed hunting avoidance behaviors as a next step ? 

## Key takeaways to better protect curlews... {.smaller}  

##### ...and other wader birds

Regarding the main foraging and roosting areas, it would be desirable to work on an extension of the natural reserve, especially toward North on the main land

To limit anthropogenic pressure in the area, it would be very beneficial to limit the effects of hunting by: 

- reducing the hours during which hunting is permitted
- limiting the density of hunting cabins (especially in the immediate proximity of the nature reserve).
